title: Domain Change Redirect Checker
metaTitle: Domain Change Redirect Checker | Verify Domain Migration SEO
metaDescription: Changing domains? Verify all redirects are properly configured. Check 301 implementation, prevent SEO loss, and ensure smooth domain transition.
heroDescription: Verify redirects when changing domains. Ensure proper 301 implementation and preserve your SEO value during domain migration.

SEO Best Practices for Domain Changes
Preserve URL Structure: Keep same URL paths when possible
No Redirect Chains: Redirect directly to final destination
Monitor Rankings: Track keyword positions during transition
Keep Old Domain Active: Maintain for minimum 1 year

faqs.question: How long does it take for search engines to recognize a domain change?
faqs.answer: Google typically processes domain changes within 2-4 weeks if properly redirected using 301s and the Change of Address tool in Search Console. However, full recovery of rankings may take 1-3 months. Keep your old domain and redirects active for at least 1 year to ensure complete transition.

faqs.question: Will I lose my SEO rankings when changing domains?
faqs.answer: With proper 301 redirects, you should preserve 90-99% of your SEO value. Expect temporary ranking fluctuations during the transition period (1-4 weeks). However, poor redirect implementation or using temporary redirects instead of 301s can cause significant ranking loss.

faqs.question: Should I redirect to the homepage or page-level URLs?
faqs.answer: Always use page-level redirects, not blanket homepage redirects. Redirect each old URL to its equivalent page on the new domain. Redirecting everything to the homepage loses link equity and creates poor user experience. Map URLs individually for best results.

faqs.question: How do I update Google about my domain change?
faqs.answer: Use Google Search Console's Change of Address tool. You must have verified ownership of both old and new domains. Submit sitemaps for both domains, and Google will process the change faster. The tool only works for full domain changes, not subdomain or protocol changes.

faqs.question: Can I delete my old domain after setting up redirects?
faqs.answer: No, you must keep the old domain active with redirects for at least 1 year, preferably indefinitely. Backlinks, bookmarks, and search engine caches will point to the old domain for years. Deleting it breaks all those links and loses accumulated SEO value.

faqs.question: What happens to my backlinks when I change domains?
faqs.answer: Backlinks pointing to your old domain will pass their link equity through your 301 redirects to the new domain. However, it's beneficial to reach out to high-value link sources (major publishers, industry sites) and ask them to update links directly to your new domain.

faqs.question: Should I change domains and redesign at the same time?
faqs.answer: No, avoid changing too many things simultaneously. Separate domain changes from major redesigns or content changes. This makes it easier to identify the cause of any traffic drops and reduces overall risk. Complete the domain change first, stabilize, then proceed with other changes.

faqs.question: How do I handle subdomains when changing domains?
faqs.answer: Redirect each subdomain individually. If you had blog.olddomain.com, redirect it to blog.newdomain.com (or wherever you're moving that content). Map subdomains carefully and test all subdomain redirects separately to ensure complete coverage.

faqs.question: Will social share counts transfer to the new domain?
faqs.answer: Unfortunately, social share counts (Facebook likes, Twitter shares, etc.) typically don't transfer to the new domain even with proper redirects. Each social platform treats the new domain as a new URL. This is one unavoidable cost of domain changes.

faqs.question: What if I'm changing domains and moving to a new CMS?
faqs.answer: Tackle one change at a time if possible. If you must do both, ensure redirects map old URLs to new URLs correctly regardless of the URL structure change. Test extensively in staging before going live, and have a rollback plan ready in case of issues.
